Fig 1 Typical raman spectra for the raw and functionalized CNTs. Fig 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of various supported Ru catalysts with different functionalized carbon nanotubes as supports. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 The adsorption–desorption isotherms of N2 on different MWCNTs (A): MCN (▽); AMCN (♢); CMCN (○); HMCN (☆); NMCN (△) and supported ruthenium catalysts (B): Ru/MCN (▽); Ru/AMCN (♢); Ru/CMCN (○); Ru/HMCN (☆); Ru/NMCN (△). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 HRTEM images and ruthenium particle size distribution of the catalysts: (a) Ru/MCN; (b) Ru/AMCN; (c) Ru/CMCN; (d) Ru/HMCN and (e) Ru/NMCN. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 NH3-TPD (A) and CO2-TPD (B) profiles of Ru/MCN catalysts with different functional groups: (a) Ru/MCN; (b) Ru/AMCN; (c) Ru/CMCN; (d) Ru/HMCN; (e) Ru/NMCN. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Carbon, Oxygen and Nitrogen 1S XPS data of different MWCNTs samples: MCN, AMCN, HMCN, CMCN, NMCN. Research paper Influence of the functional groups of multiwalled carbon nanotubes on performance of Ru catalysts in sorbitol hydrogenolysis to glycols Xingcui Guo a 1 Huihuan Dong a b 1 Bin Li a Linlin Dong a Xindong Mu a ⁎ Xiufang Chen a ⁎ a Key Laboratory of Bio-based Materials, Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Qingdao 266101, China Key Laboratory of Bio-based Materials Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology Chinese Academy of Sciences Qingdao 266101 China b School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Shanghai Institute of Technology, Shanghai, 201418, China School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering Shanghai Institute of Technology Shanghai 201418 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally. Graphical abstract Functional groups of CNTs acted as anchoring site for Ru and obstructed the sintering of ruthenium clusters which therefore maintained high dispersion on these catalysts. The nature of these groups played crucial role on the activity of sorbitol hydrogenolysis. The presence of a solid base promoter or nitrogen doping facilitates dehydration of polyols and subsequent deoxygenation while restraining the methanation reaction. Different functional groups (i.e. NH2, COOH, OH and nitrogen-doping) modified CNTs (denoted as AMCN, CMCN, HMCN and NMCN, respectively) supported ruthenium catalysts (Ru/AMCN, Ru/CMCN, Ru/HMCN and Ru/NMCN) were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method. They were fully characterized by XRD, TG, Raman, XPS, TPD and TEM to elucidate the relationship between the physical property and their catalytic performance. TEM results shown that Ru particles were well dispersed on the surface for all the samples with the size of 1.48–1.99nm. The effects of functional groups of carbon nanotubes (CNTs), nitrogen doping and base additive types on activity and selectivity of ethylene glycol (EG) and propylene glycol (1,2-PD) were investigated. In addition, the activity and final products distribution were much influenced by the properties of functional groups on CNTs and the type of metal cation of the base promoters, which probably participated in the reaction for accelerating a retro-aldol reaction for CC cleavage. Among the catalysts, Ru supported on AMCN exhibited the best catalytic activities and glycols selectivities than on MCN, CMCN, HMCN and NMCN. Keywords Hydrogenolysis Sorbitol Ruthenium catalyst Glycols 1 Introduction Biomass as sustainable and renewable raw materials was considered to be one of the most potential substitutes for the production of liquid renewable fuels and chemicals to displace petroleum in the next few years [1–3]. Lignocellulosic biomass-derived sugar alcohols were considered as versatile feedstocks for the production of useful chemicals [4]. The hydrogenolysis of sorbitol to EG and 1,2-PD has aroused considerable interest due to the wide applications of EG and 1,2-PD in the manufacture of polymers, resins, functional fluids, perfumes, cosmetics, etc [5,6]. Furthermore, producing EG and 1,2-PD from renewable raw materials can reduce human dependence on fossil energy resources and contribute to sustainable development for the environment and the economy. Over the past decades, a lot of studies have been performed on the effects of different metal catalysts (Ni, Pd, Pt, Rh and Ru) [7–10], supports and base promoters on the structure and their catalytic activity in sorbitol hydrogenolysis to glycols. Among the proposed catalyst systems, Ru was found to be the most active metal for polyols hydrogenolysis [11]. Meanwhile, Carbon materials (carbon nanotubes (CNTs), carbon nanofibers (CNFs), graphenes or graphite) were often used as supports for Ru based catalysts. In this regard Sun et al. [12] studied the influence of activated carbon as supports of ruthenium for xylitol hydrogenolysis and found that Ru/AC showed high activities and glycol selectivities. Zhao et al. [13] prepared carbon nanofibers (CNFs) and used the material to improve the selectivity of EG and 1,2-PD, however, the nano-scale CNFs would induce severe difficulty in catalyst separation and product purification for practical application. Gallegos-Suarez et al. [14] suggested that the electron-donor properties of HSAG and CNTs could stabilize the electron-rich Ru nanoparticles and, in comparison with Ru/AC, favor the formation of 1,2-propanediol from glycerol hydrogenolysis on metal sites. Among them, Carbon nano-tubes exhibit electron donor character that can modify the properties of the supported metal nanoparticles and they can be also functionalized in order to change their surface chemical properties [15,16]. Studying and clarifying the catalytic effect of a specific type of functional groups on carbon materials is very important and can provide valuable guidance to the design and application of carbon-based catalysts. Coloma et al. [17,18] studied the influence of oxygen containing surface groups on the hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde or benzene with Pt/AC or Pt and Ru-supported on graphite as catalysts, and it was found that the catalytic activities have been greatly promoted by these groups. Recently, Gallegos-Suarez [19] investigated the effect of the concentration of surface COOH groups on the hydrogenolysis of glycerol over Ru/C catalyst, and found that the presence of COOH groups increased the activity of the catalyst. But there are several types groups on the surface of activated carbon, including acidic carboxyl, anhydride, lactone, and the neutral or weakly basic carbonyl, quinone, ether and pyrone. The concentration and distribution of these different groups have some major impact on the adsorptive and catalytic performance of AC. However, due to the complexity of activated carbon surface chemistry, it is difficult to distinguish the role of single functional group on catalytic application. The surface of carbon nanotubes can be selective chemical modification through introducing some specific group. The role of different functional groups formed on carbon nanotubes can be compared in detail. Various surface functional groups should have the possibility of affecting the catalytic performances of the carbon nanotubes-based catalysts for many reactions [20,21]. Nitrogen doping has also been studied as a feasible strategy for tuning the physical and chemical properties of CNTs in a well-defined way [22]. But, the influence of different functional groups or nitrogen-doping CNTs on the properties of Ru/CNTs catalyst and the catalytic performance of Ru-based catalyst for sorbitol hydrogenolysis to glycols have not yet been evaluated systematically. In the present paper, different carbon nanotubes (MCN, AMCN, CMCN, HMCN and NMCN) supported ruthenium catalysts (Ru/MCN, Ru/AMCN, Ru/CMCN, Ru/HMCN and Ru/NMCN) were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method. Then, the effect of functional groups or nirogen-doping on the structure, metal dispersion, and catalytic performance in sorbitol hydrogenolysis to glycols was investigated carefully. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials D-sorbitol, EG, 1,2-PD, LiOH, NaOH and KOH were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Inc. Multi-walled carbon nanotubes (length: 0.5–2μm, ID: 5–10nm, OD: 10–20nm), including MCN, HMCN (the content of hydroxyl group is 3.7wt%), AMCN (the content of amino group is 2.5wt%), CMCN (the content of carboxyl group is 2.6wt%) and NMCN (the content of nitrogen is 2.8wt%) were obtained from Chengdu Organic Chemicals Co., LTD and used as received, Ruthenium chloride hydrate (RuCl3·xH2O) (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd, Shanghai, China) was used as the precursor of ruthenium. 2.2 Catalysts preparation To investigate the role of CNTs functionalization, various functionalized CNTs (AMCN, CMCN, HMCN and NMCN) supported Ru catalysts were prepared by an impregnation method. Standardly, the modified CNTs were added into the aqueous solution of RuCl3·xH2O and dispersed with stirring for 5h. After being further impregnation for 12h at ambient temperature and then the suspension was evaporated at 70°C to remove water and dried at 110°C overnight. Reduction of the catalysts were performed in pure H2 at a flow rate of 20mL/min at 250°C for 2h. The obtained catalysts are generally labeled as Ru/MCN, Ru/AMCN, Ru/CMCN, Ru/HMCN and Ru/NMCN, respectively. The loading of Ru was 4.0wt.%. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of catalyst samples were recorded on a D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (Bruker, Germany) operated with Cu K irradiation and 2θ ranged from 10° to 80°. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was taken on a Nicolet 380 FT-IR spectrometer with a resolution of 2cm−1. The High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM) images were performed on a JEOL JEM-2100F operated at 200KV. For Raman spectroscopy tests, the 532-nm line from a Kimmon IK3201 R-F He-Cd laser was used for excitation with an intensity of ∼20 Mw measured at the source. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyzes were carried out using a PHI-560 ESCA (Perkin Elmer) spectrometer equipped with an Mg Kα target. A Thermo IRIS Intrepid II XSP atomic emission spectrometer was applied to determine the chemical composition of catalysts and metal leaching after reaction. N2 adsorption–desorption experiments were performed with a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and porosity analyzer. NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD experiments were performed with a Micro-meritics Autochem II chemisorption analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a DuPont TGA-2950TA thermogravimetric analyzer. Samples were analyzed in platinum pans at a heating rate of 5°C/min from room temperature to 1000°C in an atmosphere of air. ICP analyses were carried out on a Thermo IRIS Intrepid II XSP atomic emission spectrometer to determine the chemical composition of catalysts and to examine metal leaching during reactions. 2.4 Catalytic hydrogenolysis reaction The hydrogenolysis of sorbitol was performed in a 50mL stainless-steel autoclave with magnetic stirring. After sorbitol aqueous solution, Ru catalyst and an appropriate amount of base were charged into the reactor, the autoclave was purged with hydrogen four times and then pressurized to the desired pressure at room temperature. Then the reaction was performed at certain temperature under the stirring speed of 800 r/min. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled down and the used catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by centrifugation. The samples were filtered through 0.22μm-pore-size filters (Membrana) prior to analysis. The obtained products such as 1,2-PG, EG and GLY were determined using a gas chromatography (GC, 7890A, Agilent, USA) equipped with a CP-Wax 58 (FFAP) capillary column (0.25mm×25m) and a flame ionization detector. Other products like glucose, sugar alcohols were quantified by Anion-Exchange Chromatography (IC, Dionex ICS-3000) equipped with pulsed amperometric detector and an Aminex HPX-87H column (Bio-Rad, 7.8×300mm), using 500mM NaOH as eluent with a flow rate of 0.4mLmin−1 at 30°C. The obtained products in resultant solutions were also identified by GC–MS (6890N, Agilent, USA). The conversion of sorbitol and yields of products were calculated on the carbon basis and defined as follows: Conversion ( % ) = moles of sorbitol ( in ) − moles of sorbitol ( out ) moles of sorbitol ( in ) × 100 Yield ( % ) = ( moles of the product ) × ( number of carbon atoms in the product ) ( moles of sorbitol charged ) × 3 × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts 3.1.1 Structural properties of the catalysts The Raman patterns of all the supports with different functional groups are examined to explore the influence of functionalization on the extent of disorder or defects on these CNTs. As illustrated in Fig. 1 , all the five MWCNTs exhibit two characteristic peaks at around 1340 and 1575cm−1. The peak at near 1575cm−1 (G-band) represents the tangential mode vibrations of carbon atoms in graphene sheets, while the D peak (around 1342cm−1) is corresponding to the vibrations of carbon atoms in the disordered graphite structure. The ratio (ID/IG) of the integral value of D band intensity (ID) to the integral value of the G band intensity (IG) of raman spectrum can be used to measure the disorder degree or the concentration of functionalized groups and defects in CNTs samples [23]. There is an obvious increase of ID/IG ratio for samples HMCN (1.21), CMCN (1.28) or AMCN (1.32) compared to the pristine MCN (0.91) (Fig. 1). This indicates a great increase in defects along the nanotubes’ body after functionalization. Because Ru nanoparticles prefer anchoring onto the defect structures rather than the perfect sites of CNTs [24]. So, with the increasing of defects sites, smaller Ru particles in the range of 1–3nm can more effectively be attached or loaded on the carbon support surface and agglomeration of catalyst particles is inhibited. However, a different behaviour of the band intensity at “D band” and “G band” can be observed for NMCN. The defects are induced by uniformly doped nitrogen in CNTs, which provide more nucleation sites, and thus promoting a higher dispersion of discharge products. On the other hand, it can be seen that the nitrogen-doping has some influence on the shift of “D band” and “G band” for all the given samples. The D band is upshifted with nitrogen doping which attributes to the strong positive inductive effect of nitrogen atoms, indicating that new types of disorder is appeared for NMCN. The shifts of the G-band have been ascribed to CC expansion and the changes of electronic structure [25]. The lower intensity peak of the NMCN sample as compared to the other samples demonstrates a low content of organic molecules covalently attached [26]. XRD patterns of different Ru/CNTs catalysts with the same Ru loadings are checked and displayed in Fig. 2 . The diffraction patterns of all Ru/CNTs samples show a strong reflection and a weak reflection peaks at 2θ=25.9° and 43.2°, ascribed to the (002) and (100) planes of graphite, respectively [27]. The ICP-OES results show that the ruthenium contents for Ru/MCN, Ru/AMCN, Ru/CMCN, Ru/HMCN and Ru/NMCN are 4.1, 4.2, 4.0, 4.2 and 3.8, respectively. Besides that, no diffraction signals related to the Ru species are observed from XRD, confirming that ruthenium has a good deposition on the CNTs and the size of Ru crystallites is lower the limitation of XRD decection. The nitrogen physisorption isotherms of CNTs and their corresponding Ru catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 A and B, respectively. All the CNTs show type IV adsorption isotherms with a type III hysteresis loop at higher relative pressures, according to IUPAC-classification [28], which is typical of tubular capillaries in a mesoporous material. The catalysts exhibit similar isotherms to those of their supports, indicating that the pore structure are maintained after Ru loading. The amount of N2 adsorbed on these CNTs at relative pressures less than 0.1 is very small, suggesting that micropores are insignificant in the samples [29]. As shown in Fig. 3B, The catalysts exhibit similar isotherms to their corresponding supports, indicating that the pore structure of the CNTs is not apparently changed after Ru loading. Indeed, nitrogen adsorption isotherms results demonstrate that mesopores are accounted for the majority of the total pores in the catalysts. The morphologies and structures of the different Ru/CNTs catalysts were determined by TEM and displayed in Fig. 4 . It can be seen that all the CNTs have a diameter of about 10–20nm. The ruthenium particles are distributed uniformly over the surface of different CNTs and the particle size of ruthenium species are in the range of 0.5–3nm as shown in Fig. 4, consistent well with the XRD results. 3.1.2 Surface acidity/basicity of catalysts TPD analysis is carried out to elucidate surface acid-base properties of various Ru/CNTs catalysts. All catalysts NH3-TPD profiles are displayed in Fig. 5 A. The main ammonia TPD peak appears at about 220–299°C for the Ru/MCN and Ru/AMCN catalysts, and the peak intensity is lower than that of the other three catalysts, indicating that most of the ammonia molecules are weakly chemisorbed. Moreover, for Ru/HMCN, in addition to the lower-temperature peak, another ammonia TPD peak at higher temperatures (>330°C) can be observed, indicating ammonia chemisorbs strongly, and the peak associated with the stronger acid sites further shifts to higher temperatures (∼336°C) over Ru/CMCN sample. From these NH3-TPD results, it is clear that there exists differences in the acidity among these catalysts with different functional groups. The Ru/AMCN catalyst possesses much lower acidity than those for the other Ru/CNTs catalysts [30]. The acid properties of the parent carbon nanotubes (MCN, AMCN, CMCN, HMCN and NMCN) are also investigated by NH3-TPD, and the results are shown in Fig. S1. It can be seen the NH3-TPD profiles of the various CNTs (Fig. S1) are remarkably different from each other. The desorption peaks for AMCN and NMCN during 200–400°C are obviously lower than the other three samples. The lower total acid sites of AMCN and NMCN is mainly due to incorporation of basic amino groups or nitrogen, respectively. So, the increase of low-temperature peaks for the series of ruthenium catalysts can be attributed to residual chloride from precursors RuCl3 or the desorption of NH3 from Ru sites absorption. Similarly, basicity measurements through CO2-TPD shows that carbon dioxide also reacts differently with various catalyst samples (Fig. 5B). Most of these TPD patterns show two desorption peaks at about 230–320°C that differ from a sample to another by their positions, heights and widths, indicating changes not only in the total basicity, but also in the distribution of the base strength. It seems that Ru/AMCN catalyst possesses more base sites at 250–320°C introduced by amino groups. More recently, Chia et al. showed that the acidity and basicity on catalysts was responsible for the enhanced CO hydrogenolysis [31]. So, the number of acid and base sites arises from the functional group of CNTs will be correlated with the catalyst activity and product distribution below [32]. 3.1.3 Surface chemical states Due to the inherently surface sensitivity of XPS technical, XPS analysis can also be used to discern the chemical modification on the surface of various functionalized CNTs. As shown in Fig. 6 a, C1s peaks are deconvoluted into several bands based on these literatures: the main peak at 284.5eV is assigned to sp2-hybridized carbon atoms, peaks with higher binding energies at 286.2eV, 287.5eV, and 288.9eV are considered as C-O (phenols and ethers), CO (ketones and quinones), −COO (carboxyls and esters) species, respectively [33], which are in agreement with FT-IR spectrum of different functionalized CNTs (Fig. S2, Supporting information). The π–π* transition loss peak at 291.0eV corresponds to the characteristic shake-up line of carbon in aromatic compounds. The chemical nature of the oxygenated groups on the surface of CNTs was also investigated by XPS measurements. The XPS spectra of different CNTs showing the deconvolution of the O1s peak are given in Fig. 6b. The fraction of each surface oxygen groups is obtained by deconvolution of the O 1s peak into three components, namely, carbonyl oxygen (peak at 531.4eV), oxygen atoms in CO bonds, like hydroxyl and ether groups (peak at 532.6eV) and oxygen atoms in acidic carboxyl groups (peak at 534.6eV) [34]. The O/C atomic ratio for the sample MCN (0.0187) is lower than that of the CMCN (0.127) support, but very similar to that found for NMCN (0.0178). In comparison with the other supports the sample CMCN exhibits the highest population of oxygen at the surface, most of them being carboxylic acid species (COOH). All these observations are in agreement with the TPD-MS measurements above discussed. In addition, there are N 1s signals for Ru/AMCN and Ru/NMCN catalysts. The peak can be deconvoluted in two components: pyridinic nitrogen (399.5–398.5eV) and pyrrolic nitrogen (400.8–399.8eV) [35] as shown in Fig. 6c. The two components of the N 1s spectra, prove the presence of the nitrogen atoms within the graphite plane bonded to the carbon atoms, forming hybrid of the carbon nanotubes structure. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the catalysts 3.2.1 Effects of functional groups of carbon nanotubes on sorbitol hydrogenolysis Table 1 shows the activities and selectivities of sorbitol hydrogenolysis at 210°C and 6.0MPa H2 over different supported ruthenium catalysts with Ru loadings of ca. 4wt%. The supports include MCN, AMCN, CMCN and HMCN with different surface functional groups. On the four Ru catalysts, ethylene glycol, 1,2-propylene glycol and glycerol are formed as the major products in the presence of NaOH. 1,3-propylene glycol is also detected with a significant amount. Other products mainly include ethanol, 1,2-butanediol, CH4, CO2 and some unknown compounds. As shown in Table 1, Ru/AMCN is more active and selective for the formation of 1,2-PD and EG compared with the other catalysts. After 0.5h at 210°C and 6MPa H2, Ru/AMCN provides a 27.3% sorbitol conversion and a 58.9% combined selectivities to 1,2-PD and EG, the highest selectivity to the two target glycols among the four catalysts examined. The glycols selectivities over Ru/CMCN catalyst also stay at a high level (54.2%) at similar sorbitol conversions (∼30%). While the combined selectivities to 1,2-PD and EG over Ru/MCN and Ru/HMCN catalysts decrease to 51.0% and 43.9%, respectively. The catalytic activities over Ru-supported catalysts can be ranked as Ru/AMCN>Ru/CMCN>Ru/MCN>Ru/HMCN. Due to Ru particles are evenly dispersed on the surface of carbon nanotubes for all the catalysts as shown in Fig. 4 and the characteristic diffraction peaks of Ru species are not found by XRD (Fig. 2). So the size of Ru particle is not a determining factor for the activity difference in this study. As shown in Table 1, both acidic and alkali functional groups (carboxyl or amino groups) of the surface of CNTs as binding sites for ruthenium particles have significant effect on enhancing the selectivities to 1,2-PD and EG. In order to convert ruthenium to the active species, Ru2+ cations must be reduced up to Ru0. Amino groups possessing electron-donor properties [36] can stabilize high-dispersed Ru0, and prevent its re-oxidation, mostly likely, due to possible partial electron density transfer from nitrogen atoms of amine groups on modified CNTs to ruthenium. In contrast, carboxylic groups having electron-acceptor character favor re-oxidation of small Ru0 particles as Ru2+. So Ru catalysts supported on AMCN show higher activity than Ru/CMCN. The Ru/HMCN sample shows much lower activity than that of Ru/AMCN and Ru/MCN. This dues to the presence of intermolecular interactions between the hydroxyl groups of sorbitol and CNTs, such as hydrogen bond and orientation force, etc., which hinders the sorbitol molecular adsorption on Ru metal particles [37]. 3.2.2 Effects of nitrogen doping on the activity of Ru/MCN in sorbitol hydrogenolysis The catalytic performance of Ru/NMCN catalyst is tested in a stainless-steel autoclave at 210°C and 6.0MPa H2, the result is summarized in Table 1 (entry 6). For Ru/NMCN catalyst, the two glycols with a combined selectivity of 57.2% at 26.8% sorbitol conversion can be obtained, which are higher than Ru/MCN catalyst under the same conditions. So after nitrogen is doped into CNTs support, the catalytic activity and glycols selectivity are improved greatly. As shown in Fig. 4e, Ru particles are distributed uniformly for Ru/NMCN with the size about 1.99nm, almost as large as that in Ru/MCN (1.48nm). Based on these, one can conclude that the intrinsic properties of the supports are important factors affecting the activity and selectivity of Ru catalysts for sorbitol hydrogenolysis in water. XRD (Fig. 2) and XPS results (Fig. 6) show that the structure of Ru/NMCN changes slightly after nitrogen doping. Nevertheless, no obvious difference is observed for surface texture of CNTs due to low nitrogen content. The much higher ID/IG ratio (1.21) of NMCN (Fig. 1) indicates that it contains more defects than MCN, which are induced by uniformly doped nitrogen in CNTs and can provide more nucleation sites. On the other hand, it has been reported the basicity and the electronic density of NMCN could be increased after the doping of nitrogen, which could promote electron transfer from CNTs to Ru [17] and improve the reaction activity of Ru/NMCN catalyst in sorbitol hydrogenolysis. 3.2.3 Effect of base type on sorbitol hydrogenolysis As reported before, that the activity of sorbitol hydrogenolysis depended strongly on the basicity of reaction solution [38]. The relations between the type alkali and sorbitol hydrogenolysis activity are investigated by using various alkali hydroxide at the same OH− groups content and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . It can be seen clearly that alkaline promoters have a strong influence on product distribution and all the bases can enhance sorbitol hydrogenolysis activity of Ru/AMCN catalyst. The conversion of sorbitol on Ru/AMCN catalyst with these promoters decreases in the order of LiOH>NaOH>KOH, which is reversed to the strength of the basicity. The two investigated bases LiOH and NaOH outperform the base KOH in terms of sorbitol conversion and product selectivity. Notably, sorbitol conversion reaches 97.3% and the combined yields to 1,2-PD and EG is 61.4% under 210°C for 2h when with NaOH as promoter. However, only about 84.9% sorbitol conversion is achieved and the 1,2-PD and EG yields decrease to 29.8% and 21.7% when KOH is added under the same reaction conditions. The reaction network for the hydrogenolysis of sorbitol involves complex pathways due to the multiple CC and CO bond cleavage reactions that can occur on metal catalysts or the base promoters at elevated temperatures. The conversion of sorbitol to glycols initiates with the base promoted dehydrogenation and CO bond formation. Then, the unsaturated intermediate undergoes CC cleavage via retro-aldolization to form some small molecules, which undergo further hydrogenation or hydrodeoxygenation to1,2-PD, EG and glycerol as the major products in the presence of a base [38]. This indicates that the role of NaOH promoter is to provide a favorable environment for the activation of the initial polyols in retro-aldol condensation but also in the resulting intermediates. It is found that in comparison with K+, Na+ displays a better promotional effects on sorbitol conversion as well as glycols selectivity for Ru/AMCN catalyst. This is attributed to some of the active sites of Ru are covered by K+ ions due to larger ionic diameter of K+ [39], or it can be due to deposing carbon on the surface of Ru-K, which leads to the formation of inactive carbon covering the active sites. 3.2.4 Catalytic recyclability of the Ru/AMCN in the hydrogenolysis of sorbitol The stability of Ru/AMCN is studied by thermogravimetric technique before reaction, the TG profiles of the samples in flowing air are shown in Fig. S3. There is no weight loss of Ru/AMCN catalyst at temperatures below 450°C, suggesting that Ru/AMCN catalyst is stable for sorbitol hydrogenolysis at 210°C as used in the present study. The 4.3% residual mass for the Ru/AMCN catalysts (above 650°C) corresponds to the amount of ruthenium residue. The thermal behavior of Ru/AMCN is measured by thermogravimetric technique before reaction, the TG profile of the sample AMCN in flowing air is also compared and shown in Fig. S3. AMCN starts to oxidize at around 200°C, which is much lower than the initial oxidation temperature of Ru/AMCN in the presence of Ru. This indicates that the initial weight loss temperature of AMCN is improved after ruthenium nanoparticles loaded on AMCN and Ru/AMCN exhibites high thermal stability, which is attributed to the synergetic effect that occurred at the interface of Ru and CNTs. There is no weight loss of Ru/AMCN catalyst at temperatures below 450°C, suggesting that Ru/AMCN catalyst is stable for sorbitol hydrogenolysis at 210°C as used in the present study. The 4.3% residual mass for the Ru/AMCN catalysts (above 650°C) corresponds to the amount of ruthenium residue. As stability was critical for the practical application for sorbitol hydrogenolysis, the reusability of Ru/AMCN catalyst was conducted. After completion of the reaction, the catalyst was collected from the final solution and followed by washing with water 3 times, then dried at a temperature below 110°C before the next run. As shown in Fig. S4, sorbitol conversion and glycols yields decreased to 82.9% and 40.3% after five repeated runs. No leaching of Ru was detected in the reaction solutions by ICP-OES analysis, which confirmed that Ru/AMCN catalyst was well tolerated during sorbitol hydrogenolysis, in well agreement with the TG result. The used catalyst was further characterized by XRD and TEM. It could be seen that (Fig. S5), no characteristic diffraction peaks associated with Na2CO3 structure were found clearly for the spent Ru/AMCN catalyst by XRD, indicating Na2CO3 produced in the reaction was removed completely by washing with water. The TEM (Fig. S6) results indicated that the size of Ru species had some growth compared with the fresh catalyst and their average size was 2.83nm after reaction. The pore volume and surface area from N2 physisorption data (Table S1) showed a drop of 15.6% and 16.3%, respectively for the Ru/AMCN catalyst as a result of 3.0wt% coke build-up on the catalyst surface after reaction, as determined by TGA(-MS). These results demonstrated that the partial agglomeration of Ru species caused by high pressure or the liquid phase nature of the reaction and the deposition of organic by products on the surface of Ru surface might be the main reason of catalyst deactivation. 4 Conclusion In summary, the effects of different functionalized of CNTs on the catalytic performance in sorbitol hydrogenolysis is investigated. Results indicate that these functional groups act as anchoring site for Ru and obstruct the sintering of ruthenium clusters. So Ru nanoparticles for all the samples maintain high dispersion on these CNTs. It is found that acidity/basicity of functional groups significantly improve the activity of Ru catalysts during hydrogenolysis of sorbitol. NaOH, as solid base promoter, are found to favor hydrodeoxygenation reactions at a temperature range of 210°C in the presence of hydrogen. The presence of a solid base promoter facilitates dehydration of polyols and subsequent deoxygenation while restraining the methanation reaction. The reaction liquid is almost a clear solution after filtration of the catalyst and that no leaching of Ru is detected by inductive coupled plasma (ICP) analysis. This shows that the Ru/AMCN catalyst is highly active and can be recycled to use with regeneration in the hydrogenolysis of sorbitol. coredata.dc:description: Different functional groups (i.e. NH2, COOH, OH and nitrogen-doping) modified CNTs (denoted as AMCN, CMCN, HMCN and NMCN, respectively) supported ruthenium catalysts (Ru/AMCN, Ru/CMCN, Ru/HMCN and Ru/NMCN) were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method. They were fully characterized by XRD, TG, Raman, XPS, TPD and TEM to elucidate the relationship between the physical property and their catalytic performance. TEM results shown that Ru particles were well dispersed on the surface for all the samples with the size of 1.48–1.99nm. The effects of functional groups of carbon nanotubes (CNTs), nitrogen doping and base additive types on activity and selectivity of ethylene glycol (EG) and propylene glycol (1,2-PD) were investigated. In addition, the activity and final products distribution were much influenced by the properties of functional groups on CNTs and the type of metal cation of the base promoters, which probably participated in the reaction for accelerating a retro-aldol reaction for CC cleavage. Among the catalysts, Ru supported on AMCN exhibited the best catalytic activities and glycols selectivities than on MCN, CMCN, HMCN and NMCN.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of the functional groups of multiwalled carbon nanotubes on performance of Ru catalysts in sorbitol hydrogenolysis to glycols
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
